Award.AwardTitle: GEO REU PI Workshop 2018: Boulder, CO, September 14-16, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Directorate of Geosciences supports over six hundred students each year to participate in Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site programs at about sixty institutions across the country. Competition to be accepted to these programs is fierce, with most programs having a selectivity of 6% or less. These sites provide research experiences for students who are likely to become the future geoscience workforce, and therefore, it is important that the scientists who manage them are aware of current best practices in student recruitment, career training, ethics training and other professional development practices. This award provides support for a workshop, to be held at the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research in September 2018, that will support the exchange of effective management strategies between NSF GEO REU site managers. During the two days of the workshop, about sixty representatives of GEO REU programs will meet to continue the development of community connections between REUs, offer training for new REU site directors, and allow for advances on issues such as adapting REUs for community college students, supporting students from all backgrounds, and assessing the combined impact of REU-type programs in the Geosciences. The group will also contribute to the development of a GEO REU Management Handbook.

The goal is to improve how REU Sites engage students in science through research experiences, both by improving the experience for REU participants and by broadening the student population that is accessing these opportunities. Collaboratively, the PIs will contribute to the common understanding and research base of this educational approach. The workshop is critical in achieving these goals because it allows PIs who live in geographically disparate locations to work together intensively over a couple of days.

The workshop will bring together the REU managers from across the Geosciences Directorate to support the sharing of strategies in running inclusive and effective programs. The workshop builds on prior NSF-funded workshops for GEO REU PIs in 2011, 2014 and 2016, and the face-to-face interactions between PIs has helped to facilitate the development of a community of practice in the intervening years. The 2018 workshop will have a focus on recruitment of students from Minority Serving Institutions. PIs will also learn about ways to recruit students from populations that are underrepresented in the geosciences, including students with disabilities, Veterans, minorities, first-generation and non-traditional students and those from community colleges.

This award supports NSF strategic goals of advancing the capability of the Nation to meet current and future challenges by fostering the growth of a more capable and diverse research workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This 2018 workshop was organized to bring together the NSF REU PIs of the four Divisions of the Geosciences Directorate with the following objectives: 

1. We intended to Introduce new program managers to the GEO REU community

The NSF GEO REU program accepts applications for funding and refunding each year, and so a relatively large number of new site managers, as well as replacement managers at existing sites, had not yet been introduced to the GEO REU community. Through face-to-face connections at this meeting, we believe that they have been more comfortable participating in subsequent discussions on the GEO REU email listserv, telecons, and other activities.

2.  We hoped to set a standard for best practices in running an REU and supporting PIs

The intent of the workshop was to support GEO REU PIs in achieving the NSF goals of providing undergraduate students with positive experiences conducting research, gaining professional development, and connecting with peers. The REU community (using a pre-workshop survey) and a workshop Organizing Committee identified current topics of interest for the workshop. These included: Recruiting & selecting diverse applicants, Orienting and preparing mentors, scaffolding science for academically younger students, managing REU logistics, and providing sexual harassment and ethics training to students, amongst others.

3. Our aim was to build connections between the GEO REU PI network and other internship leaders in Minority Serving Institutions

Nine faculty from Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) were invited to the GEO REU Workshop to develop connections with the REU program managers and share perspectives of what MSI faculty look for in REUs when sharing opportunities with undergraduates. The hope was to promote student applications across programs such as the NSF REU program and internships through the NOAA Educational Partnership Program with MSIs.

4. We intended to promote discussion on topics salient to the GEO REU community

Topics that resonated with the community and were highlighted during talks and sessions included the issue of increasing diversity in REU programs, preventing sexual harassment, and evaluating one's REU Program.

5. We aimed to orient and prepare new REU PIs: A one-day "Pre-REU PI Workshop" was held just prior to the workshop, where new PIs could learn about some of the basics of running an REU, and connect with each other and with more experienced PIs in a small environment.

The keynote talk by Vernon Morris, a faculty member at a Minority Serving Institution, Howard University, on "What is and insn't working in diversity efforts: Time for a change." The message he presented was that the usual approaches of seeking out students from MSIs of sending out pamphlets for faculty to share is not effective, and he presented alternatives approaches. 

At the meeting several faculty who run research internships funded by other organizations or that are hosted at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) including TCUPs, HSIs, and HBCUs were invited to the meeting. The intent was to increase connectivity between the GEO REU PIs and those at MSIs so that learning and relationship-building could take place. Listening sessions were run with the intent of having those from MSIs speak and other listen.

In addition, there were breakout groups, a Share-a-Thon event, a poster session, trainings, and talks on topics salient to the community such as how to evaluate one's REU program and how to prevent sexual harassment. 

The overall feedback from the participants was that challenges and strategies were shared, community building took place, and progress was made in learning how to deal with difficult situations and issues.
